headline: For Lesotho's textile workers, Trump's tariff damage is already done
summary: STORY: Every morning, Matsoso Lepau queues at the gates of a garment factory in Lesotho's capital Maseru for a job that no longer exists.For three months, Lepau and other laid-off workers have gathered here after the imposition of U.S. tariffs led to the widespread cancelation of orders, followed by job losses and factory closures.“It doesn't sit well with me that we come here but our lives are tough, things are really difficult.”Lesotho's textile industry - which produces jeans and other garments for popular U.S. brands such as Levi's and Walmart - is its biggest private employer.But it was hit hard when U.S. President Donald Trump announced a 50% tariff on the Southern African kingdom's exports in April.And though he slashed that tariff to 15% last week, for many the damage was already done.Lepau says he's now lost his income of between $162 and $168 a month.He hopes that the lower tariff might mean he gets his job back."The buyers, have stopped, have canceled..."Analyst Thabo Qhesi has his doubts."So, it means the 15%  didn't make the difference, you know, because the orders are not coming." Lesotho's textile industry employs around 40,000 people and accounts for roughly 90% of manufacturing exports, according to Oxford Economics.That makes it a key source of employment and foreign exchange for the poor, landlocked country.However, Lesotho's trade minister has raised concerns that the reduced 15% tariff rate does not go far enough - pointing to competition from Kenya and Eswatini, both of whom have 10% rates.

raw.headline: For Lesotho's textile workers, Trump's tariff damage is already done
raw.summary: STORY: Every morning, Matsoso Lepau queues at the gates of a garment factory in Lesotho's capital Maseru for a job that no longer exists.For three months, Lepau and other laid-off workers have gathered here after the imposition of U.S. tariffs led to the widespread cancelation of orders, followed by job losses and factory closures.“It doesn't sit well with me that we come here but our lives are tough, things are really difficult.”Lesotho's textile industry - which produces jeans and other garments for popular U.S. brands such as Levi's and Walmart - is its biggest private employer.But it was hit hard when U.S. President Donald Trump announced a 50% tariff on the Southern African kingdom's exports in April.And though he slashed that tariff to 15% last week, for many the damage was already done.Lepau says he's now lost his income of between $162 and $168 a month.He hopes that the lower tariff might mean he gets his job back."The buyers, have stopped, have canceled..."Analyst Thabo Qhesi has his doubts."So, it means the 15%  didn't make the difference, you know, because the orders are not coming." Lesotho's textile industry employs around 40,000 people and accounts for roughly 90% of manufacturing exports, according to Oxford Economics.That makes it a key source of employment and foreign exchange for the poor, landlocked country.However, Lesotho's trade minister has raised concerns that the reduced 15% tariff rate does not go far enough - pointing to competition from Kenya and Eswatini, both of whom have 10% rates.

headline: Mad Genius Unleashes Flavor Mashup Snacks in the Frozen Aisle, Now at Walmart
summary: Mad Genius Snack Lab is shaking up the frozen aisle with its flavor-fueled mashups now available at Walmart. The new lineup reinvents classic comfort foods like quesadillas, snack rolls, and empanadas by infusing them with globally inspired flavors. From spiced street food twists to unexpected fusion favorites, each snack is a bold, crave-worthy combination designed to surprise and satisfy.

headline: Bandai Invites You to Blast Off to Tamagotchi Paradise
summary: Ever since Tamagotchi pets appeared on Earth in 1996, hundreds of thousands of these adorable characters have found loving homes with humans. For the first time ever, Tamagotchi Paradise – the next device in the brand's rich history – will take fans on an interstellar journey, where the quintessential Tamagotchi play gives birth not only to a beloved new character…but an entire Tamagotchi Planet! The device has an MSRP of $44.99 and is now on-sale in North America at retailers including Amazon U

headline: New Owner of Bentonville, Arkansas Pak Mail Provides Innovative Outlook in Shipping, Freight, and Office Services in the Neighborhood of Walmart's Global Headquarters
summary: Annex Brands, Inc., a leading franchisor in the packing, shipping, and office services industries, is pleased to announce the successful transfer of ownership of an existing Pak Mail location in Bentonville, AR to new owners, Jeff and Laura Hairston. The community will benefit from the essential shipping, freight, and office services offered at this Pak Mail location of 21 years.

headline: RASCALS LAUNCHES NIGHT PANTS, PREMIUM NIGHTTIME UNDERWEAR
summary: Rascals, the award-winning, Walmart-exclusive diaper and training pants brand, is excited to introduce Night Pants, a new premium line of nighttime underwear for children aged 4-15 navigating bedwetting. Available now at Walmart stores and online across the U.S. and Canada, Night Pants are designed to help families feel more in control of their nights by providing dependable overnight protection that parents and children can rely on.

headline: Online scam uses fake ICE raids at Target and Walmart to steal personal data
summary: Viral TikTok videos claiming retail workers were deported or fired by ICE are part of a phishing scam designed to collect email addresses, phone numbers, and payment information.
